Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 2:

Dear [Referral Doctor],

I am writing to refer my patient [Patient Name] who has been diagnosed with A41.9 - Sepsis, unspecified organism. [Patient Name] is a 59-year-old male who is presenting with sepsis of unknown origin, most likely osteomyelitis. He is also displaying confusion and poor orientation of time when asked.

We initially treated [Patient Name] with IV vancomycin, and now he has been switched to clindamycin. I wanted to refer him to your care as I believe he would greatly benefit from your expertise.

Please let me know if you require additional information or have any questions regarding [Patient Name]'s referral.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear [Name of Specialist],

I am writing to refer a 39-year-old patient who was involved in a road traffic accident two weeks ago and has been experiencing low back pain, which she felt was gradually getting better until the last 48 hours. Her pain has worsened and is now associated with urinary and faecal incontinence, as well as tingling in both legs. She underwent an MRI scan of her spine that was clear and discussions with the general surgeons did not warrant for an emergency. Upon investigation with the rheumatology consultant it was determined that there was no need for assessment there, however, Neurology team review was recommended.

I would be grateful if you could offer an assessment of her condition and provide the necessary treatment plan.

Thank you for your assistance in this matter.

Yours sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral Letter 1:

Dear Neurology Department,

I am writing to refer Mr Fudge, a patient under my care, who has previously been diagnosed with G40.3 - Generalized idiopathic epilepsy and epileptic syndromes. Mr. Fudge recently collapsed in Tesco and had a tonic clonic seizure, which lasted for 1 minute and self-terminated. He then had a second seizure 5 minutes later, which lasted for 20 seconds and also self-terminated. Upon arrival of the ambulance, Mr. Fudge had a Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) of 3-15, which then increased to 14-15.

Mr. Fudge has a medical history of alcohol withdrawal seizures, Type II diabetes, and epilepsy. He is currently taking lamotrigine 200mg and has not consumed alcohol for 6-8 months. He was seen by Dr. Cossburn in clinic yesterday, who requested an MRI for suspected Wernicke's encephalopathy.

I am requesting your assistance in further managing Mr. Fudge's condition. Please advise on any necessary treatment alterations that may be required.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

I am writing to refer my patient, Mr. Reynolds, who has recently been diagnosed with J18.9 - Pneumonia, unspecified organism, as well as an incidental finding of a resting tremor in his right arm, more pronounced than in the left. During his hospital stay, it was noted that Mr. Reynolds was on chlorpromazine, which had been started many years ago for anxiety-depression. Since then, his chlorpromazine has been stopped without any further psychiatric symptoms. A DaT scan was ordered and completed by a neuro SpR, with results available below.

I believe that Mr. Reynolds' condition warrants further assessment and management from a specialist in the area. I am hoping that you would be able to see him and determine the best course of treatment moving forward. Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear Specialist,

I am writing to refer my patient, [Patient Name], to your care for the ongoing management of her complex headache condition.

[Patient Name] was admitted to our hospital [1-52] ago with headaches and blurred vision. She underwent a CT brain scan on 25-02-2019, which yielded no abnormalities. MRI brain-MRV conducted on 2-3-2019 was also unremarkable. LP on 5-3-2019 showed normal opening pressure and was subsequently discharged home with tramadol.

However, she has since developed a left-sided headache that has increased in severity. The pain is stabbing in nature with blurred vision. She feels that this headache is different from the original headache, as it is not a frontal headache like her usual IIH headache. It started with a sharp pain in the left temporal but has now turned into global pressure and heaviness.

We requested the anesthetic team to perform a blood patch, but currently, they do not believe it is necessary without evidence of low-pressure features. As a result, we would like you to review the MRI brain scan with regards to the ongoing complex headache with no symptom relief.

Thank you for your attention.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral Letter 2:

Dear Dr. ________,

I am writing to refer my patient, [Patient Name], for your expertise in diagnosing and treating neurological conditions. She is a 77-year-old woman who was recently admitted to our hospital for aspiration pneumonia due to J69.0 - Pneumonitis due to inhalation of food and vomit. Prior to her admission, she was an inpatient under section at St. Annes. Since her admission, she has developed decreased GCS, refractory hypokalemia, and hypernatremia, and we are unsure of the cause of her continuing reduced GCS. We are considering a lumbar puncture to exclude encephalitis-meningitis and other non-infective causes. If you agree, we would greatly appreciate your assessment and advice on the necessary investigations. We would also be open to the possibility of transferring her care to you if you feel it is appropriate.

Thank you for your time and expertise.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear [Referral Doctor],

I am writing to refer my patient, [Patient Name] who has been diagnosed with A41.9 - Sepsis, unspecified organism. He is a 17-year-old male presenting with back pain, lower limb pain, and occasional spasms with decreased mobility, requiring crutches for short distances and a wheelchair for school-longer distances.

[Patient Name] had a viral LRTI 4-12 months ago, after which he developed lower limb myalgia and decreasing mobility. 2-12 months ago, he was diagnosed with post-viral myalgia by his GP, as he had similar symptoms two years ago that resolved later. Recently, he complained of lower back pain, spasms in the leg, incomplete voiding, and was found in retention and catheterized. He also had spiking temps with raised CRP and was started on antibiotics for SUO. 

MRI spine and CXR were clear. CK was normal, and Rheumatology has reviewed the patient but were unclear about the pathology. Autoimmune screen, C3, C4, ENA, dsDNA, and antiCCP are currently pending. 

Please provide further treatment and management plans for [Patient Name], and keep me informed of any updates or changes.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral Letter 1:

Dear [Doctor's Name],

I would like to refer a patient to your care for further evaluation and management of his epilepsy. The patient in question is an 18-year-old gentleman who was diagnosed with adrenoleukodystrophy and was recently admitted to our hospital after experiencing a generalized tonic clonic seizure. The seizure lasted approximately 5.5 minutes before self-terminating. 

Since his admission, the patient has not experienced any further seizures, and there are no identifiable triggers for his epilepsy. He did exhibit some vomiting during his post-ictal period and has some spasticity on examination, but otherwise there are no acute concerns. 

The patient's last seizure was in 2014, and we would like to further investigate his condition to ensure that he receives the appropriate treatment and care. We would be grateful if you could see him in your clinic for further evaluation. 

Thank you for your assistance in this matter. 

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral Letter 1:

Dear Specialist,

I am writing to refer my patient for further management and treatment after being diagnosed with J18.9 - Pneumonia, unspecified organism. Attached to this letter, you will find the discharge summary for DCH and a summary of blood tests to date.

Initially admitted on 17-5-16, my patient had fever, night sweats, lethargy, aching all over, dry cough and breathlessness, vomiting, decreased appetite, weight loss & urinary symptoms. Despite being diagnosed with pANCA Vasculitis, my patient reported several tonic clonic seizures, which raised further concerns.

EEG tests showed no cerebral vasculitis, and a subsequent MRI head also confirmed no cerebral vasculitis. However, my patient's renal biopsy confirmed MPO+ve vasculitis, which explained the reduced renal function.

Throughout the hospital stay, he showed fluctuating blood sugars, requiring the intervention of diabetic nurse specialists. Heavy PV bleed was also reported, and gynae investigation showed atrophic endometrial thickening, leading to the scheduling of hysterectomy.

HAP x2 was reported, and CTPA showed bilateral upper lobe nodules-scars. Despite being negative for TB, upon discharge, my patient was put on 6-12 TB prophylaxis.

I recommend that you comprehensively assess and treat my patient, taking into account the complexities of his case.

Thank you for your assistance in treating my patient.

Sincerely,

However, we are unsure whether the SD-P shunt is malfunctioning, or whether there are partial seizures and post-ictal confusion present.

Thank you for your help in managing Nicole's epilepsy.

The episodes occur daily, and the patient is aware that they are going to happen. The patient describes becoming anxious, toes and fingers curl, arms flex, then abdomen tenses. He can recall conversations going on around him during episodes. The episodes last 15-30 minutes with a variable recovery period. There is no incontinence but sometimes he bites his tongue. The patient has had 3 similar episodes today. Following these attacks, his muscles hurt and he can get some amnesia. These episodes have never happened whilst asleep. Examination today was normal with power, tone, and coordination normal in all limbs. Cranial nerves are all grossly intact. An MRI brain and CT brain have both been carried out with results below. Dear Specialist,

I am writing to refer my patient, [Patient Name], who has recently been discharged from our hospital after a prolonged stay for treatment of pANCA Vasculitis. [He/She] has also been diagnosed with J18.9 - Pneumonia, unspecified organism.

[He/She] was subsequently diagnosed with pANCA Vasculitis and experienced several tonic-clonic seizures during [his/her] stay.

Dear Gastroenterology Team,

I am writing to refer a patient, Mr. XXXX, who was recently diagnosed with A41.9 - Sepsis, unspecified organism. We admitted him to the hospital after he had a fall secondary to sepsis from an aspiration pneumonia. Following treatment with antibiotics, the patient has stabilized and is currently in a more comfortable state.

However, Mr. XXXX has a complicated history of spinocerebellar disease, which has led to poor swallow and associated deafness. Despite assessment by the SALT team, his swallow was deemed unsafe, and we considered an NGT. Unfortunately, the patient refused this treatment, and we are now concerned that he may lack capacity given his underlying condition. With no NOK to discuss with, we are looking to arrange an IMCA to carry out a best interests meeting regarding the appropriateness of an NJT.

In the meantime, for over two weeks, Mr. XXXX has only had stage 3 thickened fluids as advised by the SALT team, which he consumes very little of. Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 2:

Dear Dr. [insert name],

I am writing to refer my patient [insert patient name] who has been diagnosed with R41.0 - Disorientation, unspecified. The patient was admitted to Ansty on 1-9-15 following a tonic-clonic seizure, which was thought to be secondary to low magnesium after starting Omeprazole 40mg QDS. The patient did not remember the events and had no prodromal symptoms. A CT Brain was performed, which showed no change in the size of the left MCA aneurysm, apart from a slight increase in calcification. There was no change elsewhere, but a small old right parietal infarct was noted. Magnesium was replaced IV, and omeprazole changed to ranitidine. 

The patient was discharged, but since then, their family has noticed them becoming increasingly confused with reports of visual hallucinations. The patient became more restless and aggressive and was brought back to the hospital. On admission, the patient reported having visual hallucinations since discharge associated with a headache. There was no history of fever, speech-visual disturbance, focal weakness in extremities, SOB-cough-night sweats, or abdominal pain, but the patient complained of some dysuria. Throughout the day, the patient became increasingly confused and agitated and absconded from the hospital, very unsteady and unsafe on their feet, aggressive, and difficult to manage. 

The patient was reviewed by the psychiatric team, which found them to be floridly psychotic. The patient had thought disorders, was disorientated in time, place, and person, and was paranoid (believing staff wanted to harm them). The patient appeared to experience auditory and visual hallucinations and clearly lacked capacity and became increasingly aggressive. They were given IM haloperidol 2.5mg initially, but this had little effect, so at MET Call was put out. On arrival, the patient needed a lot of encouragement and restraint to keep them in their room, and was grabbing their head and rolling around. They were therefore given 5mg IV of haloperidol, and their friend was then able to calm them somewhat. They were then brought up to ITU where they were Intubated and Ventilated to allow for a repeat CT Brain and Lumbar puncture for possible encephalitis.

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1: 

Dear Sir/Madam, 

I am writing to refer a 39-year old lady who was recently involved in a road traffic accident and has been experiencing low back pain. Although she initially felt it was getting better, in the last 48 hours her pain has worsened and has been associated with urinary and faecal incontinence, along with tingling in both legs. Despite undergoing an MRI scan of her spine, the results were clear and suggested the issue is not due to any spinal problem. 

I have discussed the case with a general surgeon and was informed that her presentation does not constitute a general surgical emergency, and the patient should be referred to a pelvic floor surgeon via their GP. Additionally, a medical registrar has advised that all back pain patients are to be reviewed by the rheumatology team, but after speaking with them, they do not feel it necessary for her to be reviewed by them.

Vasculitic screen was normal, and the rheumatology team was satisfied that no systemic process accounted for his presentation.

Question: Referral letter: Dear Specialist,

I am referring a 5-month-old patient who has been diagnosed with partial seizures. The baby boy was admitted to our hospital following seven episodes of abnormal movement over the previous 24-48 hours. In these episodes, his face turned red, his eyes were staring (sometimes off to the left), and he became stiff with possible slight shaking. These episodes are associated with either breathing fast or breath holding for 1-2 seconds. They all resolved spontaneously and lasted around 20 seconds, and he returned back to his normal self quickly after each episode and was moving his arms and legs normally. There was no obvious preceding cause or trigger, and he had never had any episodes like this before.

On examination, he appeared alert and active with minor mild blanching spots over his chest and back. ENT-Cardio-Resp examination was normal, and he was afebrile. Neurological examination appeared appropriate for his age. He had normal tone, normal and symmetrical facial and limb movements. His eye movements were normal, and he was responding to sounds appropriately. He had an uncomplicated neonatal history, vaccinations were up-to-date, and there were no developmental concerns or family history of seizures.

He was admitted to the ward, underwent a number of investigations, and was started on IV ceftriaxone. Routine blood tests were unremarkable, and cultures from blood and CSF did not indicate infection. He continued to have seizures, as many as 12 episodes in 12 hours. An MRI was performed under GA, which did not show any cause for the seizures, and a prolonged EEG was performed, which was consistent with partial seizures of right temporal onset. The patient was started on carbamazepine, and since then, the seizures have stopped. The baby boy will increase the carbamazepine dose to a maintenance dose of 40mg BD (20ml), and he will be reviewed in our local pediatric consultant's clinic in Poole, as well as in Southampton.

I am referring this patient to you to provide further management advice and any necessary support for future care.

Thank you for your attention in this matter.

Sincerely,

There was also no history of SOB, cough, night sweats, or abdominal pain, though the patient did complain of some dysuria. Throughout the day, the patient became increasingly confused and agitated. The patient was initially given IM haloperidol 2.5mg which had little effect, so a MET Call was put out. On arrival, the patient was needing a lot of encouragement and restraint to keep him in his room, grabbing at his head and rolling around. The patient was given 5mg IV of haloperidol and his friend was then able to calm him somewhat. The patient was then brought up to ITU where he was intubated and ventilated to allow for a repeat CT Brain and lumbar puncture, with concern for encephalitis.

Question: Referral letter: Referral Letter 2:

Dear Neurologist,

I am writing to refer my patient who has been diagnosed with R29.8 - Other symptoms and signs involving the nervous and musculoskeletal systems. The patient has had a long history of back pain. A small cervical syrinx was found when the patient presented in 2011 following a fall down stairs, and then became unable to move her lower limbs, requiring several years of rehabilitation. She has only been mobilizing for a year and presented on 19-12-15, having fallen asleep in a chair and waking up unable to lift her left arm and both lower limbs. Initially, the patient reported urinary incontinence, but that has since resolved. There were no bowel symptoms.

On clinical examination, the patient had normal tone in all limbs apart from the left hand, which was held in flexion and resistant to movement, suggestive of longstanding spasticity (patient reports as new). The power in the right arm is 5-5, while the left arm is 1-5. The bilateral lower leg is 0-5, completely flaccid. All reflexes were normal throughout without any clonus.

The patient is still unclear about the diagnosis from neurology and feels that these symptoms may have an underlying psychological aspect. We would welcome your clarification that there is not an underlying condition to her presentation. The patient has not had an MRI on this admission. As it was felt that this is most likely functional, a repeat MRI would feed into this.

Thank you for considering this referral.

Sincerely,

She's an 88-year-old lady with a history of recurrent episodes of reduced cognition-consciousness dating as far back as 2010. Despite being on lamotrigine for this condition, she was admitted to the hospital after being found unconscious on the floor. 

Our patient's condition initially appeared to improve slightly, but over a few days, she experienced recurrent vacant episodes lasting hours. Over time, she became non-verbal except for screaming intermittently, which till now, has persisted. We have treated her with limited evidence as cellulitis (due to the raised inflammatory markers and a slightly red leg), but after having ruled out the possibility of clinical seizure activity, we have treated her as delirium. An EEG performed during one of her episodes on the ward came out entirely normal. 

Our patient has seen both Elderly care physicians and a Psychiatrist, with limited success. Therefore we are writing to seek your perspective in case we have missed something potentially reversible. It is pertinent to mention that our patient has not had repeat neuroimaging since her MRI pre admission. This is because previous attempts at neuroimaging (with an MRCP) had to be abandoned due to her continual movement; therefore, sedation would be necessary.
